abstract: On Oct. 5, 1947, in the first televised White House address, President Harry S. Truman asked Americans to refrain from eating meat on Tuesdays, and poultry and eggs on Thursdays, to help stockpile grain for starving people in Europe.
snippet: On Oct. 5, 1947, in the first televised White House address, President Harry S. Truman asked Americans to refrain from eating meat on Tuesdays, and poultry and eggs on Thursdays, to help stockpile grain for starving people in Europe.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 5, 1947, in the first televised White House address, President Harry S. Truman and several cabinet members, including Secretary of State George C. Marshall, asked Americans to refrain from eating meat on Tuesdays, and poultry and eggs on Thursdays, to help stockpile grain for starving people in Europe.

headline.main: Oct. 5, 1947 | President Truman Uses First TV Address to Ask Americans to Conserve Food
